Jean-Claude Van Damme, Donald Gibb, Leah Ayres, Roy Chiao, Norman Burton, Forest Whitaker and Bolo Yeung star in this 1988 drama based on true events. This is the story of Fran Dux (Van Damme), a soldier and martial artist who travels to Hong Kong to compete in an ancient tournament, The Kumite. Frank wants to fight for his ill mentor, Senzo Tanaka (Chiao) and himself. Gibb (Revenge of the Nerds) plays fighter, Ray Jackson who also competes and becomes Frank's friend, Ayres (The Burning) plays reporter, Janice Kent who is determined to get a story on the Kumite and finds romance with Frank, Burton and Whitaker play government agents, Helmer and Rawlins who try to get Frank back to his unit and Yeung (Double Impact) plays dangerous fighter, Chong Li who fights against Frank. I grew up watching this and it's definitely one of Van Damme's best with a good cast and great score by Paul Hertzog. I recommend this 80's classic.

Review title: Pure, Honest, and Not That Bloody Martial Arts Classic !
Review_body: (Bloodsport) has it all. The quest for heroism, real martial arts, charismatic highly skilled fighter as a lead, and clever fight sequences.At the time of its release, the low-priced cinemas, nicknamed "the summery" ones in my country, were crammed by the teens who loved that new wave of martial arts movies, and that newcomer (Jean Claude Van Damme). I do remember colleagues, from school, who jumped over the school's wall to catch a movie for him. Sure (Van Damme) could prove his uniqueness among the action heroes back then (Sly), (Arnie) and (Chan). And with his impressive skills, he could be a factor of originality for this movie's repeated story.Overall, I loved the simple yet effective script. Despite being clichéd, it worked highly. However, some points were a bit weak. For instance: the motive to go to the tournament; it was only to honor the old Japanese mentor? Why that mentor didn't honor himself previously, we didn't even hear him talking in regret that he couldn't win it once (anyway, thank god it wasn't a revenge story!). The reason of chasing the lead, by the 2 agents, was for being a deserter? Not a convincing motive either! Then, the lead character. He seemed unbeatable since the start, whereas his capacities were many and rare. Not seeing one point of weakness in him led to know - pretty soon - that he would beat all of his competitors; which hurt the movie with frank predictability. And finally the way the American friend was presented for the first time as brazen to girls? It wasn't so accurate, plus there was another brazen already, namely: the Arabian contestant.Speaking of which, at one point, that Arabian contestant, who has the name of (Hussein) and the wear of headband, harasses the female American journalist, played by (Leah Ayres), and then the lead beats that impudent brat by a trick. Ok, it's so typical. Because in all, and I mean ALL, the movies produced by (Cannon Group), headed by (Menahem Golan) and (Yoram Globu), the Arabian characters are none other than a negative thing, and from all the angles. It was a point that I believe (Van Damme) paid attention to, some time early, and avoided repeating it, particularly after knowing that his movies have good popularity in the Middle East countries.I hated that they tended to insert a nude scene. Obviously, the movie had enough elements to be a success, so it didn't need this commercial entreaty. Whether the producers' idea, or (Van Damme)'s, both ways it was cheap, rather degenerate.On the positive side, (Donald Gibb), as the American friend (Ray Jackson), was incredible. I don't know why that comic and lovable actor wasn't utilized anywhere else. He's just a big body to block the way of the lead in all the movies I have watched for him; which is strange and sad. In his scenes, (Forest Whitaker) steals the camera by his utter childish reactions. Though, how he was cast as a law enforcement agent while looking like a shy kid in a high school?! The soundtrack is a trip to the 1980s. The way it comments on the events is cool. The editing, redone by (Van Damme), did solid and sedate job. Some shots were so well made, on their top is where the lead was doing his split, while what seems to be a meditation moment, in the hotel's balcony, viewing the whole country from above; aside from its sheer beauty, it was solemn, having a touch of mysticism, as if he - by activating his physical and mental capacities - managed as a human to be higher than the city's skyscrapers, appearing as the king of Honk Kong.There are 2 extra reasons that helped this movie to be a success. Firstly, seeing (Van Damme) doing the split; it was sort of unprecedented for a movie star to do, turning into (Van Damme)'s most famous trade mark, so how about doing it - in the same movie - for a total of 7 times! Secondly, the poster's picture with (Van Damme) flying in the air heading for pointing a kick to his opponent by his feet; a move that next video games based upon this movie I think. That not-CG-picture fascinated many male, mostly very young, viewers back then, and you can see how posters for movies like (The Next Karate Kid), 6 years later, would copy it.In 1996, (Van Damme) kind of remade (Bloodsport) as (The Quest); a movie he wrote, directed, and starred. Although it was a flop, but that mirrors his true passion towards that hit movie from 1988, which launched him along with showing some of the most important martial arts fights since (Bruce Lee)'s (Enter the Dragon - 1973). And - sorrowfully - it mirrors his downhill within less than 10 years of his career's start as well.Save its negativities, it's a fun time with pure, honest, and not that bloody martial arts. I didn't run into these certain qualities, gathered in one movie, that much before or after. Simply, the entertaining B-movie wasn't that entertaining unless few times in history. It's a fair example for a formulaic low-budget action that could be the best of itself, and with its plain themes, smart choreography, hip music and capable lead, it became not only a hit in its time, but a cult classic. Sometimes a mix of simplicity and efficiency is an equation for being classic.

I've been pretty harsh reviewing Jean-Claude Van Damme movies, and even though he is significantly older than me, I have the feeling he can still kick my butt, so maybe I should back off a little.Honestly though, this one is pretty watchable. Make no mistake, it is no Chinatown, but, who cares, it is a fun way to hit all the tropes of the martial arts genre and it does it in a way that you know is going to be copied, even if it was already kind of a copy of Enter the Dragon only without the art.So, what you have is a bloody trope filled film that is fun to watch and vaguely (in the vaguest sense of the word vaguely) based kinda sorta on a true story that one guy said happened and was never really verified.So.... sit back and pop some corn, you'll love this.

"Bloodsport," the 1988 debut vehicle of Belgian martial artist and "actor" Jean-Claude Van Damme, opens with one of the most impressive montages of fighters preparing for the Kumite, an illegal full-contact mixed martial arts tournament held in Hong Kong. It gets the audience ready for the bloodiest cultural display of martial arts combat in decades.We're told that there are three ways to win a match in the Kumite:1) You knock the guy out2) The opponent gives up and shouts "matte," which is like saying uncle3) You knock the other fighter right off the matEnter into the picture, clean-shaved United States military intelligence officer Frank Dux (Van Damme), of whom this film's story is supposedly based off of. Dux became the first Westerner to win the Kumite, after going AWOL from his post (and two officers including Norman Burton and an underused Forest Whitaker are dispatched to retrieve him), and used his superior combat training, indomitable spirit, and iron will to defeat the legions of vicious opponents sent his way. Dux (like, "put up your dukes") is first introduced as a teenager, coming under the tutelage of a venerable martial arts master who instructs the young man in a brutal regiment of non-stop combative training to prepare him for the Kumite.Once in Hong Kong, Dux befriends fellow American Ray Jackson (Donald Gibb), also a Kumite fighter, and the two prepare for combat. There is a lot of mystery surrounding this illegal martial arts tournament, which has its origins in ancient Chinese culture. No one will talk about it, especially to nosy reporters like Janice Kent (Leah Ayres), much less pick fights outside the ring, which would result in an automatic disqualification if a brawl took place outside the Kumite.When it comes time for the action of the great tournament, 40 or so fighters look over one another, eager in anticipation of jumping into the ring and duking it out. But Dux and Ray are prepared, but nothing can ready them for the hulking South Korean fighter and current Kumite champ Chong Li ("Enter the Dragon" Bolo Yeung), who has a reputation for fighting dirty and is rumored to have once killed one of his opponents.The validity of Dux's story and military background have come under intense scrutiny in recent years but I'm not paying any attention to it. All I can do is pay attention to what's in front of me. "Bloodsport" is a perfect star-making vehicle for the Muscles From Brussels, though some studio execs didn't think so. Van Damme had to fight like there was no tomorrow to get "Bloodsport" released and even then, the critics were still not impressed but who cares? It's no where near as bad as it was made out to be, it still made the man a star, and the basis for one of my favorite fighters from "Mortal Kombat," Johnny Cage.Director Newt Arnold keeps a fine pace but the only things that seem to hold it back are some cheesy moments of levity and Van Damme's acting (surprise, surprise). Again, who cares? "Bloodsport" is a martial arts movie, first and foremost - why a need for acting? When the combat begins (with action choreographed by the real-life Dux himself), blood flows as one fighter after the other is knocked out leaving a titanic duel between only-standing Dux to duke it out with the brutal Chong Li. In between, though, we see many great styles from all over the world including straight-up Chinese gong-fu, Karate, Hapkido (my own current style of training), Capoeira, Sumo, Monkey, Muay Thai, and some good old-fashioned American brawling.Even in recent years, "Bloodsport" is still a wholly decent affair that does get bogged down in some cheap Hollywood theatrics. Van Damme doesn't seem to be fairing well either in these times, but we still have this film and some of his good earlier works to appreciate.7/10

'Bloodsport' certainly suffers from all of the problems any movie from this era and of this genre naturally would, but just as Frank Dux triumphs over Chong Li, so too does 'Bloodsport' conquer the cheese factor.Jean Claude Van Damme may not exactly be De Niro, but he has an easy, natural charisma that lifts everything around him. Combined with his impressive physical gifts--here at their absolute peak--and you have a star making turn.Filled with colorful characters, fun fights and a host of awesome 80s trappings, 'Bloodsport' is a genre essential, and a Van Damme classic.

Review title: Van Damme fans should get what they want here, but it's not an entirely satisfying film
Review_body: Frank Dux (Jean-Claude Van Damme) decides to turn his back on the military so that he can compete in the Kumite (which is a full contact fighting tournament held in Hong Kong). However, this is a no-holds-barred event where participants have been killed in the past. This competition puts Dux on a collision course with the undefeated champion Chong Li (Bolo Yeung) and Dux finds that he must pull out all the stops in order to come out of this competition alive.Bloodsport contains many of the staple ingredients that you can expect from a Van Damme film; wooden acting, cheesy dialogue, a predictable story and some rather in-your-face direction. I personally think these things form part of the charm with his films and with these expectations in mind I seldom criticise his films for continually serving these things up (sometimes I just like watching these nonsense films). There are however some things which are not really forgivable in a JCVD film such as....POOR PACING; I think part of the problem here is that this film seemed to introduce unnecessary elements which did seem to slow the film down - the two officials going to Hong Kong to try to get Dux out of the competition which seemed to just act as an unneeded sub-plot. I also could have done without the underdeveloped and uninteresting love interest with the news reporter as well. These aspects served no real purpose and should have been omitted from the story - yes I'm aware it's based on a true story, but how about just focusing on the interesting stuff? The story is also quite poorly developed which wouldn't be as much of a problem if it was a fictional story with a fictional character in the lead role. However, Bloodsport is based on a real character and it perhaps could have offered a little more insight into its central character.Despite the above problems, the 'meat' of the film is actually quite good - the fight sequences are pretty good (although many of the fights are a bit too short for my liking). The fights are quite brutal here and director Newt Arnold leaves very little to the imagination - there is one truly horrific scene that caused me to look away from the screen. The friendship that blossoms between Dux and Ray Jackson was also quite a nice angle to the story.I quite enjoyed Bloodsport, but what really lets it down is its rather poor pacing and its lack of insight which I've previously mentioned. Taking everything into account though this is an OK film which should please Van Damme fans.

Incredibly based upon the true story of undefeated Kumite champion Frank Dux is this action schmaltz from writer Sheldon Lettich and director Newt Arnold. The whole pic is nothing but an excuse for a whole lot of karate chopping, bone crunchin', blood letting brutality that shows us some neatly choreographed fighting, but zero mentality.The hopelessly lame plot is truly an insult, and it makes this pic perhaps even less bearable than a martial arts doco. Van Damme isn't asked to do much, but when he fights he looks petty impressive. Alongside him are some fearsome lookin' dudes, with nasty Bolo Yeung (as Chong Li) showing off with some flexing of his well rounded pecs. Notably, Forest Whitaker appears in the support cast (though to this day he's probably wishing he hadn't).Saturday, February 15, 1997 - Video

Review title: More pro wrestling than martial arts
Review_body: I don't know what Nunjitsu is supposed to be, but the fight moves featured in this movie are a lot closer to Vince McMahon-style pro wrestling than anything I've ever seen at the judo club at the mall.They do flying drop kicks, arm holds and nut shots that are straight out of Monday Night Raw. Then the American doofus turns his back on the ''bad guy" to his detriment. And for the final laugh, the bad guy pulls out the ''secret dust" and tossed it into his opponent's eyes. Man, I saw that shtick on Stampede Wrestling in the 70s.I'd hate to think any kids signed up for martial arts lessons based on this farce.On the other hand, the ladies will enjoy the beefcake. Van Damme had a finely tuned body. We see more of his rear end than we do the blonde he's sleeping with. The producers knew their audience.

Jean-Claude Van Damme is known for his athletic and flexible abilities. But for some that may feel that they do not see enough, should see this movie for that reason alone. The physical look of Van Damme is just one marvel alone. There is no muscle line that isn't visible on his torso because it is so well toned. Also while fighting, Van Damme makes some crazy looking faces.Van Damme plays Frank Dux, a man with a background in martial arts and military combat. The character, Frank Dux, is actually a real person and amazingly enough, Dux was the man to train Van Damme and get him ready for his role in this movie! Dux's history is shown to us in the very beginning of the film where we see a boy who is taken under the wing of a martial artist. From there he trains with him until he is old enough to participate in the Kumite. The Kumite is a world tournament that has fighters come from all corners of the earth to compete in the ultimate competition to be called the world's greatest fighter.The hardest thing to deal with this tournament is that any possible way of winning the match is allowed. Some of the things done against opponents are can get the blood boiling because it shows how players are willing to do anything to win. It's the perfect reason why the title of this film is called "Bloodsport". However, because Dux is enlisted in the military, he is not allowed to par-take in such events; but this does not discourage him. Actors Norman Burton and Forest Whitaker play the two gentlemen, who try and catch him. But there is no point to having these characters in this story. It's not that they're obnoxious but they don't encourage the plot to move on. All they do is slow it down or completely stop it in its tracks.Fighting in the ring along with Van Damme's character is Ray Jackson, played by the husky and rather giant Donald Gibb. At first, in the beginning of the film, I was almost convinced that Jackson was going to be the main enemy but he turned out to be likable and reliable friend to Frank Dux. And although, Jackson is clumsy now and then, he still packs one heck of a punch. He knocked out an opponent with one knock on the head! That's tough!Another part I didn't understand why they didn't include this character enough was Janice Kent performed by Leah Ayres. Fine and dandy that she becomes Dux's love interest and spends one night with him. But after that she's left in the corner and never talked about again. Why? If she's going to play an important role, make it important, not just 3/4 of the way through the movie! The music, by Paul Hertzog was a good touch though. The tunes had a strong zen feel and at points where Dux was super focused, it almost felt like you're there with him too.Bloodsport contains the blood it promises and has impressive fighting matches. Now if only the crew could figure out what to do with the minor characters. But the rest is entertaining all the same.

Review title: JCVD has arrived with a vengeance!
Review_body:
"Bloodsport" is where it all began for Jean-Claude Van Damme's movie career. There are several styles of martial arts on display during the course of the film. 
 The person who JCVD is playing - Frank Dux - is allegedly a fraud. He can't prove that he set all of those records during his so called distinctive career advice a martial artist. 
 It's great to see Bolo Yeung in action again and playing a ruthless competitor during the martial arts tournament.

This story to this movie is very straight forward, that's what's so nice about it. Van Damme enters a fighting tournament and tries to win it, meaning that this movie mainly consists of fighting between Van Damme and some random Chinese people. The plot is as transparant as a glass door, but why should this bother anyone? The villain is incredibly unsubtle, Van Damme is implausibly good, but this is pretty much exactly what I expect from this sort of flick. It doesn't stop me from rooting for Van Damme, nor does it really kick me out of the story. The fights, especially the inevitable showdown with Chong Li, are pretty spectacular. None of them look particularly convincing given that the punches miss by about a mile, but the choreography is still beautiful to look at. This is one of my favourite guilty pleasures.

Directed by Newt Arnold. Starring Jean-Claude Van Damme, Donald Gibb, Leah Ayres, Bolo Yeung, Forest Whitaker, Norman Burton, Roy Chiao, Ken Siu, Philip Chan. (R)Van Damme, in his breakthrough role, plays Army Captain Frank Dux (a real person, believe it or not), who goes AWOL in order to participate in a "secret" full-contact martial arts tournament--quotation marks applied because it seems that anyone, be it a bland reporter (Ayres) or witless military investigators (Burton, Whitaker), can score good seats. Slim and silly showcase for the athletic star is far funnier than it is exciting; writing and acting are both pure amateur hour, and even the fights aren't especially well-staged or executed (relying too much on slow-motion and hard cuts that interrupt any balletic grace on display). Gibb, of "Revenge of the Nerds" fame, seems out-of-place as a competitor, but if "Enter the Dragon" could sell us on John Saxon, well... Has gained a considerable cult following over the years, and in defense of the picture's fans, it really is the best way to see Van Damme drop into a split to deliver an uppercut to an opponent's nether regions. Followed by several sequels, none of them featuring the Muscles from Brussels.28/100

Bloodsport, I believe, was a great success when it came out. I only just saw it, and I can't say I thought it was deserving of much respect. I had to laugh at the terrible acting, and the myriad ridiculous excuses for showing that damned Van Damme split.Basically, the movie is Karate Kid meets Mortal Kombat, but neither the story nor the actors offer any excitement. There is about one good line; when Jackson walks in on Van Damme doing the split thing, he says, "Hey, be careful with that; you might wanna have kids one of these days!"The fights in this movie are nothing special, although of course Van Damme is capable of some impressive kicks. Compared with a half-decent Hong Kong produced kung fu movie, however, Bloodsport is hopelessly inferior and profoundly unimpressive.For the cheesy silliness of it all, I'd give this a 3 rating, but because it is (supposedly!) based on the life of a real martial artist, I'll be a good sport and rate it a 4 out of 10.

I am, of course, a cinema purist. I can't stand watching films on TV if they are going to be interrupted by commercials or edited in anyway. I won't even start watching something I have not seen unless I started at the very beginning and went to the end. However, with a couple friends over and a little Mystery Science Theater 3000 atmosphere, I threw all those rules out the window and experienced the last hour or so of the cult classic Bloodsport. Did I watch it as a piece of art? Not really. It was more the spectacle of cheesy 80's aesthetic and campy acting/dialogue that kept me from turning the channel. Was the first hour something important? Who knows, and who cares. I got the gist of what was occurring and from fight to fight knew who the hero and villain were and found myself needing nothing more.I love the tagline for the film"The secret contest where the world's greatest warriors fight in a battle to the death." How misleading is that statement? The connotations to Mortal Kombat are unavoidablewith rumor being that Johnny Cage is mirrored off our lead character Frank Duxbut to the death is a bit of a stretch. One fighter dies in this film, ONE. When he is murdered, the judges and crowd turn their backs on the killer, unable to condone the brutality. I want to know who marketed this and give them a high-five for skewing the truth to sell some seats. The movie could never be a to-the-death fight and work. Not only would we lose all respect for our hero, but also he would never be able to take a life as shown on screen. The tournament would have been shut down too, with American military cops showing up, people everywhere knowing about the event, and reporters going undercover for a story. If death was prevalent, not even the Triads could keep it up.The beauty of the film, though, is in its soundtrack. Synthesizers and falsettos abound transporting you back in time to bad acting, teased hair, and crazy characters. Every second is chock full of unintentional comedy and my friends and I had a blast with it. Jean-Claude Van Damme made a name for himself off this film, and he does not disappoint. Deserting his army post in order to go to Hong Kong to fight and avenge his master's death, this American fighter has the thickest Belgian accent possible. Maybe they explain that he was naturalized as a US citizen in the time I missed, but either way I guess it doesn't quite matter in the grand scope of things. You cannot get enough of his slow-mo shaking body and wide eyed defiance on the battle mat nor the hammy looks of fear once his adversary Chong Li gets embedded in his head to the point he even manifests him on the bus. His romantic involvement with a reporter is also laughable. There is no chemistry between them at allI think there might be more between he and friend Ray Jackson played brilliantly by Donald Gibband the relationship culminates in a horribly orchestrated scene of them bowing to each other hand over fist. At least it is an ending to put a smile on your face, not from contentment, but from sheer absurdity that you stuck with the story its conclusion.In the end, however, you have to see the film for one performance only, Forest Whitaker as the army cop. No, just joking, what the hell was he thinking doing this film? The real reason is Bolo Yeung as Chong Li. This guy is the epitome of evil. The guy is massive and his menacing stare down is so scary you have to laugh from fear or else you may soil yourself. His silent screams and excitement are so unnecessary and out-of-place that they actually work. This guy doesn't need to scream or yell. You actually start thinking he may be a mute until he finally tells Van Damme he is going to kill him before the final fight.Is Bloodsport quality cinema? Is it even nostalgically worth seeing as a piece of art? The answer is no on both counts. Would I stop flipping channels and watch it next time its on TV? Definitely. As a comedy, the film is wonderful. I can't even say the fighting is spectacular because it is always subverted by laughs. Between the guy acting like a monkey and the Sumo hugging people into submission, every single second is priceless and unforgettable.

An American soldier (and closet karate master) flies to Hong Kong to fight in an outlawed tournament with opponents around the world. Among them is the Korean champ who has never lost and has all the records. However not given permission to go the soldier goes AWOL and two guys are sent to retrieve him. I still remember seeing this one in theaters nearly twenty years ago. Of course Bloodsport introduced to us a younger and more agile looking athlete who could do the splits and actually got the girl. (Chuck Norris never did.) however years later the movie maintains most of it's watchable edge and this movie is a rather well made low budget effort which has some dynamic action sequences and enough cheesy ballads to make this essential to the seasoned genre fan.* * * out Of 4-(Good)

Review title: The Bar for All Others - A True Karate Classic (On Par With "The Karate Kid"
Review_body: Blood Sport – what can I say, I thoroughly enjoyed the movie. Is it formulaic? Well yes it isand I like "formulaic" stuff. Come on, if it's not formulaic, it's some "artsy production." And I don't watch artsy movies. Just me. With that being said, this is about the only thing, that I have seen, I really enjoyed starring Jean-Claude Van Damme. Unlike Ralph Machio's "Karate Kid", this guy already knows skills. What skills you say? Well, back then, most of us didn't call this kind of fighting 'martial arts' – we referred to it as 'karate.' Why? Well probably because we didn't know anything else back then – with the exception of "kung fu" of course. If it wasn't for David Carradine, we wouldn't know that much. Getting back to "Blood Sport" and what it is about. A-hooga – A-hooga"Spoiler Alert" – "Spoiler Alert": A guy walks into a room full of 'karate guys'; picks a fight with each one and ends up kicking all their butts. Pretty much the "Karate Kid" between adults and without the "wax-on-wax-off" dialogue. Does this sound familiar? It should since now-a-days every movie is pretty much the same basic story. The only difference between this movie and modern productions is that now-a-days, the hero is either a woman or a cartoon character. I am fine with that, like my opinion matters. The script, writing and direction are all functional. A basic good verses bad gala event with all sorts of fighting and groans and grunts. Good wins over the ultimate evil-doer and everyone skips off scene to meet the next vile no-good-nick. This movie was all Van Damme's and why he didn't get an Academy Award, I will never know.

Bloodsport is no high art and it with today standard where it all about the craft and the acting it maybe consider a bad movie but without it we will never got a Jean Claude Van Damme when Bloodsport not only make him famous but also shape his career into what we know and love today.Arguably there far better movies about martial arts tournament than Bloodsport like Enter The Dragon with better fight scenes but I still hold the movie close to my heart because there something about a guy with worst English than his sensei entering a bloody event with his loveable but obnoxious friend that make this movie so enjoyable.Because I love Hong Kong style of action where anything is quick and brutal so at first the fight scenes in Bloodsport for me kinda slow and not that interesting but from time to time when I get used to it the fight scenes turn out very believable and realistic in many ways.

Review title: A cult classic best martial arts Van Damme Style movie!
Review_body: Bloodsport (1988) is my favorite action Van Damme movie. It was the first movie I ever saw about Van Damme that introduced me in to his movies. This is the film I grew up with it, I have first see it, when I was 8 years old! I love this movie to death! In my opinion is Van Damme's best martial arts film! Beside Hard Target, Bloodsport is one of his best movies till date. I Love it so much. Best martial arts movie, is never boring, is fast and entertaining and It is awesome seriously. And I still love it today, Bloodsport also introduced me in to martial arts. Jean Claude Van Damme's Bloodsport is still today it's best. After this movie there were a few copycat movies that copy the idea from this movie. Like were Bloodfight (1989) with Bolo Yeung returning, with the same name, but playing different character from the Bloodsport and Bloodfist (1989) with World Kickboxing champion Don "The Dragon" Wilson. I also love the music from this movie lately it helps me a lot the song "On My Own - Alone", I also love the song "Fight to Survive".This is my favorite tournament fighting film too. This film also inspired the video game Mortal Kombat and for that? This film is twice as awesome to me. This is a film where you see JCVD at his peak and this is my second favorite JCVD flick after Hard Target and Universal Soldier. It holds up really well to this day and it's a shame the film does not have a special edition on DVD and Blu Ray. The film does have a big cult following so it not getting any features to this day is lame. Great concept, great cast, charismatic characters, bad ass fights, and a kick ass soundtrack. This is definitely one of the best martial arts flicks ever made without a doubt for me. Fell in love with the film ever since I saw it on VHS when I was a kid.As for the Bloodsport sequels? For the most part? They all suck. They can't even hold a candle to this film. Bloodsport is a classic and a fight that is worth watching anytime, anywhere. I still own this movie on VHS and on Blu-ray. I don't have the DVD I don't need it. I am going to say it again I love this movie to death, it is my childhood JCVD film and I grew up with it. I have always enjoy it. It has a real bloody bad-ass fights. Van Damme and Yeung kicks fighters to the ground. Original this movie was almost never released, but Van Damme helped edit the film so that it could be released, this movie is praised and loved all over the World including Asia, USA and East Europe. The real Frank Dux was the fighting coordinator for this film. When Jean-Claude Van Damme was cast, Dux announced that Van Damme wasn't nearly in good enough shape, and put him through a 3-month training program. Van Damme called those three months "the hardest training of his life" - this despite being a world-championship martial artist in his own right.It does feel good to go re-watch films like this especially dealing with the very sad fact that films like this classic aren't made anymore and seeing Van Damme these days on film, he just seems to stone faced or depressed. I have enjoyed training sequences, flashback sequences on Frank Dux's earlier childhood life and a life of a young man. The chase sequences where Helmer and Rawlis are chasing Dux was hilarious and very entertaining. Chong Li, in my opinion, is one of the best non horror villains out there. My personal favorite JCVD villain and my favorite martial arts villain. Also, though it isn't the same character; almost like a bizarro world version, another Chong Li appears in a movie called Bloodfight (Bloodsport knockoff) played by Bolo Yeung. Van Damme maybe had some problems in his later years, but I always admired him for everything he did to make this movie well known back in '88, from re-editing the original cut to promoting the movie by putting posters of it himself in cinemas. This movie for me is a perfect 10, I don't care what anyone says.

I like Van Damme, but this film is just not good enough in terms of direction, story, characters and dialogue. The action is watchable, but I'm not a big fan of movies that have only martial arts fights in 'em - This one has an entire tournament.

Review title: Only die-hard JC Van Damme fans need apply
Review_body: BLOODSPORT (1987)Aspect ratio: 1.85:1Sound format: Ultra-StereoBelgian beefcake Jean-Claude Van Damme made his name in C-grade video fodder like BLOODSPORT before hitting the big time in a series of mid-range Hollywood blockbusters (UNIVERSAL SOLDIER, TIMECOP, etc.). Here, he portrays real-life kickboxing champion Frank Dux, one of the few westerners to triumph in the Kumite ('koo-mih-tay') tournament in Hong Kong, an underground full contact martial arts contest whose final rounds are often fought to the death. However, all 'facts' aside, the movie amounts to little more than an excuse for as many bone-crunching, bloodthirsty fight scenes as the script will allow, building to the inevitable showdown between Van Damme and his only comparable opponent, a hulking Chinese villain (HK movie veteran Bolo Yeung) who has already lain waste to every other competitor in the tournament.While the action scenes are reasonably effective, the dramatic interludes are fatally compromised by bland staging and cheapskate production values (director Newt Arnold appears to have helmed only three films over the course of a lengthy career, during which he's worked mostly as an assistant director on some of Hollywood's biggest movies, including THE TOWERING INFERNO, THE GODFATHER PART II and BLADE RUNNER!). Love him or loathe him, Van Damme is the film's trump card: Captured here at the height of his physical prowess, he strikes an impressive figure during the various combat sequences, where his aptitude for gymnastics and contortion are displayed to full effect. Leah Ayres (THE BURNING) is mere decoration in the thankless role of a journalist who beds Van Damme in an effort to worm her way into the ultra-secret tournament (only to end up falling for him anyway - ho-hum), while Forest Whitaker (a year before BIRD established him as a major talent) and veteran actor Norman Burton play Army cops with a warrant to arrest an AWOL Van Damme on sight. Police officer-turned-actor Phillip Chan Yan-kin (HARD-BOILED) cameos as - you guessed it - a police captain who turns an unlikely blind eye to the Kumite, while Donald Gibb is Van Damme's tournament buddy, a big American blowhard whose arrogance is painfully tempered following a gladiatorial encounter with Yeung. The script was co-written by Sheldon Lettich, one of the more talented figures in the low budget action arena - he wrote and directed LIONHEART (1990) and DOUBLE IMPACT (1991), along with the genuinely impressive ONLY THE STRONG (1993) - but BLOODSPORT has little to offer anyone other than die-hard fans of impoverished HK movie wannabes. Three sequels followed.

Review title: Great film, don't watch the sequels
Review_body: The script may not be the best, but the action is top-notch.Bloodsport is exactly what one can expect from an 80's Western Kung-Fu flick. There's redemption, an intense rivalry, and a ton of action. Throw in Jean-Claude Van Damme and you have a proper 80's thriller.This cult classic is simple, satisfying, and BA. Don't take it too seriously and the bad acting becomes an asset instead of a liability. It's hard to find a film with this level of originality today.Shout-out JCVD for pulling this role with near-perfection.4.5/5.

JCVD plays Frank Dux, a U.S. Army Captain who goes AWOL to compete in the Kumite—an illegal and deadly full-contact martial arts tournament held once every five years, to which only the world's best martial artists are invited—with his main motivation being to pay respect to his sickly mentor (Chiao) who took him under his wing. Burton and Whitaker (the only two to offer halfway decent acting) play CID officers on the hunt for Dux. Despite bad acting, disappointing choreography and endless clichés, none of the paper-thin characters are exceptionally unlikable (though this might be because they're so poorly developed) and the Hong Kong setting is captured so vividly. Based on unconfirmed claims by the real-life Dux.*½ (out of four)

This is one of Jean-Claude Van Damme's best films. Majority of people will say it's his 'best' film, and I will find that hard to disagree with if that's the case. I liked everything about Bloodsport. The fights. Everything. What I liked most about Bloodsport was the music. I can't believe how good the music actually was. It fitted very well with the film. Some of the songs are 'Fight To Survive' and 'On My Own'. Let's not forget the rest of the soundtrack. The music made this film very good. Jean-Claude Van Damme plays a character named 'Frank Dux' who is a martial artist. He decides to leave the military, so he can compete in a martial arts tournament known as the Kumite. It's a illegal tournament held in Hong Kong. Frank Dux goal is to become the champion. Can he become the winner? You need to see it to find out. I rank Bloodsport along with Jean-Claude Van Damme other films such as 'Kickboxer' and 'Sudden Death'. There are others too, but the ones I've mentioned are some of his more popular ones. Let's not forget the fighting - that's where the real action starts. Unsurprisingly! Van Damme dominates inside the ring against all his opponents. His most challenging fight was the final where he was up against the current champion Chong Li. That fight against Chong Li was amazing! I really liked the music in the background during that fight. It fitted well I thought. Also, let's not forget Frank Dux friend called Ray Jackson. He made this film interesting to watch. I like how Ray and Frank become real good buddies. They both complemented each other. There are other characters too, but you need to see it first to get the whole picture, and understand what this film is about. Review title: Van Damme kicks his way to international stardom in his starring debut.
Review_body: Many audiences either like Jean-Claude Van Damme or they dislike him. Either way, in the late 1980's and throughout the 1990's there was no bigger star than Jean-Claude Van Damme. Van Damme had appeared in a few small movies but in 1988 Bloodsport launched his career into super stardom by showcasing his spectacular martial arts abilities and athletic prowess. Although Bloodsport was not a critical success and it certainly did not set the world on fire with its acting, it has developed a reputation as a cult classic and also attracted a legion of loyal Van Damme fans.Jean-Claude Van Damme plays Frank Dux, a US Army Captain who has gone AWOL to participate in an illegal martial arts tournament named the Kumite which is well known to be secretive yet brutal. Frank Dux participates to honour his master Senzo Tanaka (Roy Chiao) who took Frank under his wing as a child and taught him the ways of martial arts. Upon Frank's arrival in Hong Kong, he befriends fellow American competitor Ray Jackson (Donald Gibb) and liaison/manager Victor Lin (Kenneth Siu). Frank also finds himself heading towards a collision course with the defending champion Chong Li (Bolo Yeung), who is a vicious and remorseless fighter who has killed participants in past tournaments. At the same time, Frank finds himself romantically involved with US journalist Janice Kent (Leah Ayres) who has been assigned to investigate the Kumite, and Frank must also avoid being arrested by two Military Police CID officers Helmer (Norman Burton) and Rawlins (Forest Whitaker in an early role).Van Damme had a likable presence throughout his halcyon days and nowadays his star isn't as bright as it used to be as his career is stuck in the doldrums of endless forgettable direct-to-video movies. Here in Bloodsport, Jean-Claude Van Damme has a certain charisma about him along with his athletic prowess and that's what attracted many audiences to see Van Damme's movies.Don't listen to the nay sayers and forget the hokey acting, Bloodsport is still an enjoyable and entertaining martial arts movie years later. Bloodsport is definitely one of Jean-Claude Van Damme's most memorable movies in his starring debut and certainly one to remember as the movie that launched his career.Highly recommended for all Van Damme fans as well as fans of martial arts movies.7/10.

Review title: Surprisingly pleasant film in its genre
Review_body: Newt Arnold directed this Hollywood debut appearance of Jean-Claude Van Damme in 1988. Damme is young here, but does perhaps his finest performance here. He plays the real life character Frank Dux (check the IMDB Crazy Credits section for more details!) who participates in the secret martial arts contest held in Hong Kong every fifth year. There are many fighters and different martial arts, and the scenes of fighting are plenty and stylish and occasionally even Hong Kong style, which means lots of slow motion, lots of high jumps and different fight styles and great use of camera during the fight scenes. I didn't have any expectations about this film since I'm not any fan of Van Damme's. He does decent performance in John Woo's US debut Hard Target, but I'm not particularly interested in Damme's films, but watch them gladly if an opportunity appears. In Bloodsport, he acts also decently and never irritatingly, which is great thing. I think this is his most noteworthy performance because he is pretty natural here and does the fight scenes with skill (as always, though). I think fans of martial arts films and especially people who practice martial arts like this film. The fight scenes are not too realistic as in real life, these kind of punches and kicks would've killed a person, but it is usually the case with these films, but definitely don't try this at home!The music is as 80's as possible with "great" Kumite song performed by some 80's pop/rock band, and there are also some great pieces of electric music in here. The best parts of the film are the scenes at the contest since, as I mentioned, the fight scenes are so stylish and interesting due to their cinematic technique. The title Bloodsport title is explained at one point, so there is fair amount of violence and blood in this film, so don't try to watch it if unrealistic violence and this kind of stuff offends you; necks are snapped, blood is spat, but only sometimes fighters are really hurt or even killed. I don't know what the experts of martial arts think about these films that don't show the real results of this kind of violence, but probably they wouldn't like it. I found this very noteworthy piece of martial arts action films and in its own genre, it gets an 8/10 rating from me, but if you are interested in REAL martial art movies, start to track down films from Hong Kong and Asia. And there are MANY others than Bruce Lee, Jet Li and Jackie Chan as they are only the most popular fighters of the Orient.

Although it has aged quite badly as most films of this type from the eighties have, Blood Sport is a favourite from my youth and is one of Van Damme's best early efforts. There are no strings and no CG here so the fights are all the more impressive, and it is always refreshing to return to those days. The plot and characters may be simple, some of the acting may be amateurish, and the music may be dodgy but Bloodsport remains an enjoyable no-brainer for fans of the star or genre.Van Damme stars as Frank Dux, a soldier in the US Army. He has been trained by Tanaka all his life in martial arts, and wishes to travel to the infamous Kumite tournament in Hong Kong to avenge his friend's death. The Kumite is a tournament which attracts the best and most vicious fighters from around the world, many of whom are seriously injured or killed while taking part. Dux breaks orders and travels to Hong Kong, but two soldiers follow him in an attempt to bring him back. There he meets Ray Jackson, a fellow fighter and Janice Kent, a reporter trying to get an inside scoop on the tournament. From there we see many fights as Dux progresses in the tournament whose defending Champion Chong Li (Bolo Leung) is a deadly killer. Naturally they meet in the final.Once the plot devices of revenge and honour are put in place all we have to do is sit back and watch the fights. They are well-staged, there is a fair amount of violence, some humour, and the main cast do as well as could be expected. This is a must for Van Damme fans, but there will be little for anyone who does not watch martial arts movies.7 out of 10

Review title: One of my favorite martial arts movies.
Review_body: Bloodsport. Oh the childhood memories of watching a bunch of dudes beating the absolute crap out of each other. Yeah, the story's a no-brainer; its the eighties after all and these films didn't have a deep plot to begin with which is acceptable. Back in those days, the fight scenes were much better compared nowadays with all the hyper-edited, attention deficit disorder fight scenes that todays movies have. It's a shame that most directors don't sit up and take notice of these past films and turn up much better product on their part. Can't say anymore about this film but its fight scenes are great despite being a little annoyed at seeing Van Damme doing the same kick over and over again. Good lord, is that his signature move? Shouldn't matter because it's made so long ago. And Forest Whitaker is in it!! It's a solid flick just to kick back to.

I quite like JCVD's work, and this was his real breakout role, but he has released far far far greater films since Bloodsport. I recognise this fits a very niche part of cinema, but it's just not good. I assume the vast majority of those with speaking roles were not actually actors, as bar from three of them they were all terrible. One was Ayres (the only woman in the film), another was a very young Forest Whitaker (which is strange to see), and finally Bolo Yeung, who - although barely speaking - is superb as the evil foe.The choreography is a mix of great and very poor, some of the fights are brilliant to see, others have guys forgetting which way their head should rock when they're hit. The climactic fight is worth waiting for with some cool slow-mo shots, split between JCVD's insane facil expressions.The story and plot is actually fairly good, but the fact that the real Frank Dux convinced even a single person that this is a real story is a travesty. Beyond laughable. He claims to have inflicted 56 consecutive knockouts in a single tournament, which would require 10 times the world's population to be participating. I am yet to find anyone who fought in this Kumite in my day to day life.

An underrated and inspiring film for all martial arts fans.Van Damme shines here because this role is perfect for him. He doesn't need a stuntman, because he performs all the scenes himself. The choreography is good, as is the directing itself.The characters are fun, and that's what makes this movie so good. Bolo Yeung is absolutely brilliant and intimidating as the villain Chong Li. The film definitely has charm and possesses some timeless quality.The film is interesting for several reasons, not only as a film about martial arts, but also as a drama that speaks in its simple way about human emotions. It is easy to identify with the characters, because they are portrayed humanly, emotionally and above all through the prism of the friendship. Jean Claude Van Damme is first and foremost an athlete, not an actor, and this film is perfect for him and maybe that's why everything here works as it should.This film impressed me because of its charm and simplicity and because it reflects the spirit of another time. The film has truly fulfilled its primary task, it is entertaining and easy to watch. What matters is that this movie can be watched many times and is always just as fun.Courage, loyalty, friendship and honor are the values that this film
celebrates and that in itself is commendable.A cinematic work that definitely deserves its place in the history of martial arts films.

Review title: Enjoy JCVD's karate, forget about the acting and the plot
Review_body: Jean-Claude Van Damme was a little known body builder who starred as an extra in films like "No Retreat, No Surrender," before "Bloodsport" transformed him into a big star. The plot of "Bloodsport" is as basic as it gets. Frank Dux (JCVD) is the classic underdog who has the potential to be a great martial arts sensation. Dux gets to realize this potential in a competition among the world's best fighters, known as the Kumite. There are the obligatory scenes showing that Dux has some flashes of martial arts genius. Then comes the fight scenes which all end predictably right up to the big fight at the end. Along the way, this film also borrows the worn out formula of the Rocky IV movie in particular. Yet "Bloodsport," despite its simplicity and formulaic plot, is a fun kind of film. Van Damme is not a great actor, but he is an appealing one all the same. Moreover, the martial arts sequences are a lot of fun especially when accompanied by Paul Herzog's 1980s music soundtrack. Then there is the apologetically macho dialogue which is of course lame, but fortunately also unintentionally funny. Lines like "Very good, but brick no hit back," and "You break my record, now I break you like I broke your friend" are abound in this film. Lastly "Bloodsport" benefits from two surprisingly good actors. I have known my fair share of martial arts masters and Roy Chiao's performance as Senzo Tanaka is as authentic as they come. Unlike Miyagi, who often has a twinkle in his eye, Roy Chiao plays Tanaka with a straight face and shows only grudging admiration to his promising student, Dux. It's truly a fresh take on the Miyagi character. Another actor that brings a lot to this film is Bolo Yeung (playing Chong Li) who does not have a lot to say, but can communicate a great deal by how he reacts to Dux's surprising progress over the course of the Kumite.

Review title: A classic in martial arts cinema.
Review_body: Jean Claude Van Damme... the name written all over the poster. Van Damme gived a fine martial arts (not acting!) performance! Saw this as a kid, forgot how it looks, until again on DVD... and I say... no matter how this film is crappy, or funny, I say - good! Low budget film that is well known to all martial artists and Van Damme fans! Everything is low budget! But good! Van Damme deserved all the credits after this film, seriously! A story of Frank Dux, a french karateka trained to become a champion of Kumite tournament (played by Van Damme), based upon a true events, or something. In this Kumite, we also have a heavies as Donald Gibb (Ray Jackson), an everlasting funny guy! And Bolo Yeung (Chong Li), a creepy, bad acting, but charismatic dark fighter. I loved Bolo here, he was always bad ass on films, and he is perhaps one of the most worthiest opponents to Van Damme on screen. Leah Ayres is a first Van Damme girl, a sexy journalist that tires to infiltrate to the tournament. Also... the great surprise... Forest Withaker, from younger days. I was so happy to see him here. This film is very powerful, really great martial arts stuff! Watch it and enjoy!

Jean-Claude Van Damme stars as Frank Dux the first American to win the "Kumite" in this fun chop socky actioner which contains breath-taking actionscenes as well as an alright story. Bloodsport is also one of Van Damme's better movies, it's not saying much, but overall Bloodsport has a fun plot and is recommended for fans of the genre.

Review title: honoring a true C martial arts classic!
Review_body: First, the director (Newt Arnold) had been a co-director all his life, and appeared notably as a naked old man in a sauna prank scene in "Porkies"... This should lower our expectations enough because we aren't dealing with dePalma, Tarantino etc. The script is no Lumet either. Although supposedly based upon true life events happened to the real Frank Dux ( who in later years went through litigation with Van Damme over the higher budget spoof of "bloodsport", "the quest" ), the plot is as thin as a spider web. However, this is the 80ish martial arts movie like people loved it to be. Plenty of well-choreographed fight scenes, a decent score by Herzog ( ala Rocky IV) and extra subplots like the romance one (which i read is often a requirement to have the screenplay approved ) and the police chase, which are stitched together for the sake of it. 8-10 because it is a true classic, without much plot frills like those Hues, Rothrock, Norton 80ish movies.If you want a "message" or true realism, go watch Karate Kid I; if you want excellence in fighting, go watch Bruce Lee...

This is probably the first martial arts movie I've seen. I've watched it probably more than a hundred times and still didn't get tired of it. It's not only about fighting scenes, they were pretty good, though sometimes looked too fake,but still there was some nice moves and some bloody moments who were very impressive. But like I said, it's not only about martial arts, it's a great movie in other terms too. There was many touching moments, like that dialog between Frank Dux and Tanaka at his son's funeral or the last fighting scene. There was many other touching moments and I would like to write about it but I'm afraid, it may spoil the movie. The soundtrack was great, it really fit in this film. After Bloodsport, many similar movies were made, some of them had a better fighting scenes but still this is my favorite movie of this type and will always have a special place in my heart.

Review_body: An intimidating and cool villain with awesome fight and training sequences, 80s music that never gets old and remains catchy, and humor/romance mixed in in the right moments! I proudly love this movie!

Review title: Great Martial Arts Movie from the 80's
Review_body: I had never seen a van Damme-movie before this one. And oh boy, I was surprised in a really positive way. The best thing about this movie is that it's from the 80's. That means really GREAT music, and in this movie, the music makes up a really magnificent atmosphere for the viewer through the whole film. Of course, the fighting is good. It's not just good, it's great. It was really exciting to see different fighting styles from all over the world. And Bolo Yeung did a really great job as the villain. He barely talks, but shows with his behavior that he is Mr. ruthless himself. The final fight with van Dammes trademark, the 360-kick, shown several times in slow motion, is a feast for the eye. Hong Kong is the location for the movie, and the city fits perfectly for it. Enjoy!

If someone asked me about 15 years ago how I would rate this movie, I would've given it a 9 or 10 instead of the 6 I just gave it.  Seeing this movie now it's so easy to see the silliness and bad acting that plagues it. However, as far as Van Damme's career this was the film that made him a superstar and, in my opinion, the one role that he personified the best. That's saying a lot, because watching this movie nowadays I realize how BAD his acting was, but then again he's here for his martial arts skills.  Not to say he's that good because there are COUNTLESS people better than him....Van Damme is a ballerina compared to true martial arts experts like Jet Li, Jackie Chan, Donnie Yen, etc etc.  Everyone knows the story by now; the movie on a whole is entertaining, but it seems more like a comedy than a martial arts biopic.  There's silliness everywhere, from the dialogue to the actual fight scenes themselves; so much that you can't help but think that the makers of the film really went overboard with their 'dramatic license', and hardly any of the events in the film really happened.  Still, if I had to pick a Van Damme film to watch and enjoy, I'd choose this almost everytime.**1/2 out of **** stars.

I am a fan of the great action star Jean-Claud Van Damme and this movie by far is one of his best movies along side his other great action movies like Kickboxer,Nowhere to Run,Timecop,wake Of Death and Sudden Death.This movie is good and there are heaps of great fight scenes all through out this movie and there are some good actors and actress in this movie like Forest Whitaker who is a really good actor,Leah Ayres,Donald Gibb from the movie Revenge Of The Nerds,Norman Burton and Bolo Yeung. Or a dramatized adaptation of a beefcake magazine. That's the vibe I got from this. Van Damme and his sweaty abs look like they think they're in a 80's softcore parody of Enter The Dragon with 'acting' to match. The movie itself pulls a Confessions of a dangerous mind (2002), in that it purports to be a "true" story based on one man's unverified claim - the real Frank Dux is a known liar/exaggerator, with a lot of the stories he told the screenwriter later being shown as such. With this story, Dux got a buddy of his to corroborate it. Later after they had a falling out, the friend said Dux coached him to say it. And yet the male bimbos who defend this still buy into a story with nothing to back it up. I guess that's why they call it a cult movie.
You spend 20 minutes watching live-action Action Figures (Van Damme even looks like he's made of plastic) kung-fu fight (choreography that's been done better in almost any other kung-fu movie you can think of) and 70 minutes wasted on a purile hyper-cliche cardboard excuse for a plot ("I must avenge so-and-so by competing in this sport/tournament for some reason!") just to frame those 20 minutes where things actually happen. It's like seeing the Karate Kid as a grown man who went on to star in yet another brain cell killing Mortal Kombat movie. And it's all smathered with an extra coating of '80's cheese.

It's fun to watch Van Damme pirouette and high step and do splits and all that. The fights are ok, but there are instances where they look very fake. For example, one guy is supposed to be hitting another guy's head with his knee, but you can clearly see that it's not hitting him. Bolo Yeung has a nicely villainous mein. The claims about the real life Frank Dux are pure hokum. The man is a fraudster of the most ludicrous kind. For example, the movie claims that he knocked out 56 men in a row to win a tournament. No tournament can have 56 rounds. The number of participants would be 2 to the 56th power, which is over 9 million times the population of the earth.

Review title: The film that consecrated Van Damme as an action star is also the one that had his best acting!
Review_body: A young American soldier, trained, when child,by a master in martial arts, escapes from the United States with the objective to go to China and participate in a secret tournament, famous for its violence,as a form to honor his teacher's memory.Once he is there, he ends up falling in love for a beautiful journalist who is there to report the event, at the same time in that he needs to use all the force and technique he acquired with his master to survive...and to win.The film that consecrated Van Damme as an action star is also the one that had his best acting. Efficient and entertaining,"Bloodsport" counts with combat scenes filmed with extreme professionalism and realism, what can shock in some more violent moments (there is a particularly explicit scene, in which the villainous breaks the opponent's leg, and the bone comes out). Director Newtt Arnold balances the adventure scenes with the dramatic touches of the plot, what turns "Bloodsport" into an excellent show not only for those who admire martial arts, but also for those who like a nice entertainment. The prominences goes to the exceptional performances of Van Damme and Leah Ayres, and for the final fight between Van Damme's character and the Chinese champion, an unforgettable and touching part that summarizes all the experience and the talent of this great movie star!

Review title: A violent and fast film played to perfection by Van Damme, Leah Ayres and Bolo Yeung...
Review_body: A young American soldier, trained when child by a master in martial arts, escapes from the United States army with the objective to go to China and become one of the fighters of a secret tournament,famous for its violence, believing that this is a way to honor his master's memory. Once he is there, he ends up falling in love with a beautiful journalist who is there to report the event, at the same time in that he needs to use all his force and technique to survive and to win. The film that consecrated Van Damme as an action star is also the one that had his best acting. Efficient and entertaining, "Bloodsport" gives us combat scenes filmed with extreme professionalism and realistic choreography, what may shock in some more violent scenes (there is a particularly explicit part, in which the villainous break his opponent's leg, and the bone comes out). The director Newt Arnold balances the adventure elements with the dramatic touches of the plot (and in this more serious moments, Van Damme demonstrates a surprising talent) what turns "Bloodsport" into an excellent show not only for those who admire martial arts, but also for those who enjoy a fast and interesting entertainment. The prominences go to the exceptional performances by Van Damme and Leah Ayres, and for the decisive fight between Van Damme's character and the Chinese champion (played by Bolo Yeung, in a terrific interpretation- his character, Chong Li, looks like a furious psychopath), an unforgettable and touching moment that summarizes all the experience and agility of Jean Claude Van Damme!

As the years go by and the world is more subjected to MMA, UFC and K-1 events in the mainstream, the one that started it all had to have been Bloodsport. Think about it, did anyone give a damn about K-1, MMA or anything like that in the early 1980's? Out comes this movie and 20 years later kickboxing has become more popular than regular boxing and wrestling.Based on true events, Bloodsport centers around a secret underground kickboxing tournement called the Kumite (pronounced Koo-Mitt-Tay) that has been around for thousands of years. Jean Claude Van Damme plays Frank Dux (as in put up your dukes), an American of French decent who stumbles upon an old Chinese martial arts teacher who teaches him the way of the warrior so to speak. Many years later the teacher is near death and Frank pledges to win the Kumite in his honor. Standing in his way is Chong Li (Bolo Yeung) , the current champion along with Helmer and Rawlins (Forrest Whitaker), two American agents assigned to bring Dux back to the US unharmed since its revealed Dux is a captain in the US military and wasn't supposed to be in this thing.I say the actual Kumite scenes were done well in terms of the actual fighting but the transition and timing was downright awful. In one scene Chong Li snaps Suan Parades (Tong Po from Kickboxer) leg and then the next scene shows Dux fighting someone else with Parades sitting in the stands unharmed. I think the Parades/Chong fight was supposed to be one of the last but it fit better in the music montage so they jumped the gun with it. Later on the big sumo Pumala is visbily shown sitting behind Jackson and Lin, and while he's fighting Dux and Monkey Man you can clearly see him sitting in the same spot while he's supposed to be on the runway. Also, Dux and Chong Li looked to have fought about 10 guys between them in the first 2 days of the tournement yet Ray Jackson (Donald Gibb) fights twice on the first day yet makes it to the last fight of the second day? One last thing, Dux beat his guy in 12 seconds to set the world record and later on I timed a fight where Chong Li beat a black guy in 6 seconds....wouldn't that mean he got his record back? The good news is the actual fighting and different styles more than made up for the clumsy editing and the story lines/sub plot fit well with the overall point. Donald Gibb was hilarious in his role, and its always nice to see Tong Po with hair. Bolo Yeung looks younger than Van Damme and was a short time away from his 50th birthday during the course of filming, I didn't even believe it until I checked the bio....hell he's pushing 75 now and I bet he could make a comeback in one more flick.I don't want to give away too much but if you want full contact bloodshed and Ogre from Revenge of the Nerds throwing people around one more time, this is the movie for you. Yes there is a love plot between Van Damme and Leah Ayers and if thats not your thing hit the fast forward button, otherwise sit back with your gi and enjoy the movie. The highlight of the movie is Ricardo Morria aka The Monkey Man, you'll know what I mean once you see the movie.7 out of 10 (3 points off for the bad editing)

Review title: Do you really think this is good?
Review_body: Well... When I was a kid "Bloodsport" was one of my favorite movies. Really. This was one of the first martial arts movies that I saw and I loved it. But then I saw "Romeo Must Die"... I am not saying that "Romeo Must Die" is great but it is much better than "Bloodsport". Then I saw more Jet Li movies and I thought that most of them were great. You could read my other comments and you will understand. But I still loved "Bloodsport"... Until I saw it again. Is that the movie that I used to love? The story was dumb, the acting was bad... But who cares about the story and the acting? All we want is fighting, isn't it? But even the fights in this movie were bad. I mean very bad. Most of the time JCVD actually does not look like he is fighting. He just shows us how muscular he is. His moves are slow and his enemies do not move. They just stand there and wait for him to hit them. The fight with Bolo Yeung was pathetic. Really bad choreographed and terribly shot and... Well, I don't think it could be called a fight - each one of them just stands there and waits for his turn to hit. Bad, bad, bad... Why the fights are so bad, why? I am giving the movie more than 2/10 just because it was entertaining to me when I was a kid.

Review title: Cult film highlighted by excellent martial arts
Review_body: Bloodsport is a martial arts film about Frank W. Dux, an American who travels to Hong Kong to participate in an underground martial arts tournament known as the Kumite. Although it's based on real events, it's clear that Bloodsport isn't very accurate in that measure. The fighting styles are authentic though.Jean Claude Van Damme plays the role of Frank. He definitely gives the appearance of someone who could win the tournament, but otherwise his acting is poor. Bobo Yeung plays the bad guy and manages to equal Van Damme's quality in acting. The rest of the acting is terrible, with the lone exception of Donald Gibb as Ray Jackson, another Kumite participant who becomes close friends with Frank during the tournament.The directing is mediocre. It was especially bad during the beginning (the flashback sequence was completely unconvincing), but improved as the Kumite became the focus of the film. There are very few artistic moments, perhaps the alleyway scene going to the tournament being the most effective one.The redeeming element is the fighting. Every tournament battle is unique and offers contrasting martial arts styles. Van Damme is especially impressive in his technique. I also liked the fact that each Kumite participant had a distinct personality.As it stands, I could see Bloodsport being entertaining for most people, but I could only seriously recommend for people who love martial arts. It succeeds in bringing tournament action, but fails at building any drama.

Review title: Bloodsport: At times entertaining, but could easily be much better
Review_body: It didn't start very well for Jean Claude van Damme. His breaking through, "Bloodsport", is a flick that could have been so much better.First of all they could have changed the script. At times Bloodsport is almost an adventure-movie because of unnecessary elements and therefore rather unrealistic. I would like it to be more of a fake-documentary or a documentary "wannabe" which only focus on Dux and the tournament. The character Jannice Kent has really nothing to do in this feature, she just makes it worse.The music is contemporary and therefore boring. I would like "Bloodsport" more if it had more Chinese music or something corresponding to create more mood in the film.Newt Arnold´s direction isn't really weak but it could have been a more interesting view with less editing, more pans with the camera together with slow and quick zooms.The fact that "Bloodsport" is short for being a feature is just a plus, but some of the fights could perhaps been longer and they could perhaps also having some more fights without spoiling the overall impression.Overall, Bloodsport is for me a big disappointment that misses it's potential but in the same time at some moments a good movie.Rating: 4+ of 10.

Review title: Van Damme, always in my heart.
Review_body:
Bloodsport, "Bloody Sport, or Bloody Contact," as it was called in Spain, is a special film in many ways.To begin with, it was Van Damme's real debut on the big screen. It is true that he had already participated in five films before: The most savage among all, Monaco Forever, Disappeared in combat, (is uncredited), and Breakin, all of 1984, and as the Russian villain, as was usual at the time He never retreated in 1986. But all these papers did not serve to throw him into stardom, since they were low-budget films that barely reached a small sector of the American public.Feeling that his career did not seem to have much exit, Van Damme decided to play it "all for everything", and in 1988, two years after his last film, which shows the difficulties he was going through to make his way in Hollywood, He went to Hong Kong to shoot, "Bloodsport", an independent film with his first role as protagonist. It was a very modest film in the media, but for the first time Van Damme would have the freedom to show his full potential, not as an actor, because in that he was still very green, but as a martial artist, where all his strength and charisma resided.
The bet was a success to his measure. The chosen director, Newt Arnold, one of the most reputable directors of the second unit of the moment, made what would be his third and last feature film. His work in the film was quite good, taking into account that this man had never made a film of martial arts, most of the shots and frames during the matches are simple but superb, without the need to make the viewer go around a thousand times with the camera, as with many martial arts movies now.Likewise, the recreation of the tournament was quite efficient, creating all that fascinating and sordid clandestine atmosphere, and with those dark alleys of the huge apartment blocks, showing the most sinister side of the Hong Kong city.Van Damme as Frank W Dux, fulfilled what was expected of him. It is not that he performs a great performance, in what refers to the dramatic scenes, but his poses and facial gestures during the battles supplied those shortcomings, especially in the final fight.The casting of wrestlers was the greatest success of all, as they were all real fighters and even champions in their respective specialties such as Paulo Tocha, Attilio Reale or John Law among others ....Attention also to a young man Forrest Whitaker, in his first roles and who still struggles to understand what he does in a movie like this.The variety of styles is considerable, the Brazilian wrestler Suan Paredes showing a curious mix of boxing and capoeira, the Samoan Pumola with a mixture of sumo and wrestling, the companion of Dux, Jackson, wrestling and street, the Spanish fighter Paco, with a very aggressive style, and something rustling, everything must be said, of Muai Thay, as well as many others like kung fu, judo, karate, wing Chun etc ...he fights denote a rawness and realism that I have rarely seen in similar films and in fact the director insisted that the fighters do not stop and really hit if necessary, and that is seen and palpated visually, dotted with Pretty blood, honoring the title. Some fights are spectacular but others, however, are very brief and sometimes too unrealistic. It is noted that there were many cuts, because many of the secondary combats give the impression of having been originally more extensive.Also, as in Kickboxer, it is not explained because in the final fight the villain always slaughters Van Damme initially, but at a given moment, it seems to become a statue merced by the blows of the Belgian.The movie, Chong Li, played by Bolo Yeung, is the best of the film. Raw, sadistic but with an admirable determination and strength, cheating if necessary, anything goes to win, is clearly superior to the rest of the fighters, with that laughter and facial expressions, giving it an almost demonic dimension. Truly, Yeung's work is what makes this film great.The soundtrack of the very underrated Paul Hertzog is simply huge. I have never seen melodies that transmit so many sensations and accompany fights so well. The theme "Powder", for example, every time that Chong Li jumps to the tatami is chilling, making clear the danger of this fighter.In definíva, is Bloody Contact a good movie ?. If we had to be cold and honest the answer would be no. It does not count on good performances, its technical level is of series B, and the choreographies are regular.But this is a movie that is carried in the heart. If you saw her as a child and seduced you, then you will never be able to see her as I said above.It will always seem the best of the best, a film that you will see ten thousand times and you will never get tired of feeling the adrenaline rush while watching the blows and falls of those gladiators to the rhythm of "Fight to Survive". Or to feel the euphoria when seeing the "And I'll kill you" of Ray Jackson to the hated Chong Li, or to get excited and jump off the couch dreaming of being in the place of Van Damme kicking Chong Li ...After all, childhood is a wonderful time, and films like this made it even better. Of that there is no doubt.Thank you.

Review title: The movie that started it all
Review_body: I saw this movie in 1988 when I was 13 years old. I rented a copy in a local video store. Everyone was talking about it at the time especially about Jean-Claude Van Damme, who only did some small roles in movies like "No retreat, No surrender." This time he was the main character. Bloodsport tells the story of martial arts expert, Frank Dux (played by Jean Claude Van Damme), who travels to Hong Kong to participate in a dangerous underground competition known as the Kumite. Frank Dux was trained by Tanaka whose son recently died and was going to participate in the Kumite tournament. Frank decides to compete and represents the family name of his master, Tanaka. But Frank has a little problem, he is a special force for the US Army and getting hurt in the competition is not a luxury for the army. The army decides to send agents Helmet (played by Norman Burton) and Rawling (played by Oscar winner Forest Whitaker) and follow Frank all the way to Hong Kong.On his journey Frank meets a big roughneck American call Ray Jackson (played by Donald Gibb) who becomes his friend and is also participating in the tournament. Frank also meets an attractive young reporter Janice Kent (played by Leah Ayres) who wants to write an article of the underground competition. The competition is fearless with fighters from around the world and introduced different styles and disciplines of fighting. Frank toughest challenge is Chong Li (played by the legendary Bolo Yeung) a menacing and ruthless fighter who will stop at nothing. The movie has its cheesy part and the music, well it's the 80s, but our IMDb need to understand that BloodSport is a low budget movie and it launched the career of Van Damme as a mayor action star. It even inspired other movies like "Kickboxer", "Shootfighter", "American Samurai", and more, it also inspired video games like "Street Fighter" "Mortal Kombat" and "Fatal Fury". Years later the Ultimate Fighting Championship introduced us with real live fighters from around the world with the same format as the movie. These are some of the reasons "Bloodsport" should be consider as a classic. So, if you seen this movie, I invite you to rent it or buy it and travel the time machine of memories. Those who haven't seen it, I make the same invitation and see the movie that started it all.

Review title: Not an "award movie", but great nevertheless...
Review_body: Let me say it right now, if you watch Bloodsport expecting the same kind of satisfaction you got from movies such as Crash, Ray or Brokeback Mountain (to name a recent few), you shall be very, very disappointed. However, if you watch it as it's meant to be watched, that is to say as a no questions asked, straightforward, martial arts tournament movie, then it is a truly great film.Based on an allegedly true story, there is no deep meaning to Bloodsport...but it isn't meant for one to be there. The acting is not mind-blowing, but once again, it's not meant to be. You know exactly what's going t happen in the end, but who cares? This is a movie you can watch again and again, just because it's not all about the story.All in all, Bloodsport is an entertaining flick, with a decent story, decent acting, great music by Paul Hertzog, and great fight scenes. A movie that will satisfy your martial art needs.
